Award.AwardTitle: Conference: A Strategic Planning Workshop to Explore Quantitative Biology as a Vehicle for Broadening Participation to be held at Spelman College on March 11 and 12, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The principle investigator is from Spelman College and is an expert in Systems Biology. Systems Biology is a field of biology that argues that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts, and that true understanding of complex and dynamic biological systems requires the incorporation and integration of fundamental principles derived from mathematics, physics, engineering and computer science. This understanding is thought to be necessary for harnessing the full potential of biology to sustain life on earth. The project will involve academics and administrators from regional Atlanta institutions and Spellman alumni who hold faculty positions at prominent research institutions. The workshop will explore and develop a strategy for implementing a novel educational framework that would prepare diverse student populations for collaborative research at the intersection of disciplines. The workshop is motivated also by the realization that underrepresented groups might gravitate more naturally toward the computational areas. As such, this workshop offers significant broader impacts through inclusion of several minority-serving institutions and regional research one institutions.

This project is based on a novel way of thinking about training a future workforce in times where the convergence and integration of disciplines becomes the new standard. This direction is characterized by the recognition that emergent properties of biological systems are unlikely to be realized through reductionist approaches that generally reveal details about individual components, but contribute little toward an understanding of how these components interact to sustain live under ever-changing conditions. This workshop also represents a new model for how to advance education and research training at the intersections of disciplines, with a strong emphasis on a broader involvement of underrepresented groups in the "new biology" academic setting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On March 11-12, 2016, over sixty participants from 17 universities and colleges attended a workshop at Spelman College to discuss how to strengthen research and education in the field of quantitative biology at local Historically Black Colleges and Universities.

 

On the first day, the workshop started with a presentation by Dr. Eberhard Voit from Georgia Tech entitled, “Systems biology: Excitement, opportunities, challenges” which provided a broad overview of the field.  The following presentations by Dr. Sanjukta Hota from Fisk University, Dr. Gregory D. Goins from the North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University, and Dr. Derrick Hylton from Spelman College introduced the participants to three distinct approaches implemented in their respective institutions to infuse quantitative skills in their courses. The session was followed by a panel of graduate students and faculty from underrepresented minority backgrounds who discussed their experiences, both positive and negative, as they pursued their graduate education or career in quantitative biology. The panelists described the importance of the mentoring they had received in the STEM disciplines.This panel discussion also highlighted the importance of soft skills for navigating graduate school programs. In addition, most underrepresented minority graduate students benefited greatly from on-campus champions and advocates to navigate the new environments at graduate schools.

 

On the second day, faculty participants discussed challenges and opportunities for strengthening education and research in quantitative biology at HBCUs, best practices for developing institutional collaboration between HBCUs and Research Intensive universities, and ways of increasing computing capacity at HBCUs.


Overall, participants agreed that the interdisciplinary nature of quantitative biology makes it both a challenge and an opportunity in STEM education and for fostering collaborations between faculty to implement innovative curricula and pursue new research avenues. In addition to pursuing research and teaching-related goals, participants stressed the importance of creating a sense of community while mentoring students. Support for these multiple facets would create an environment that can sustain faculty engagement and increase the participation of underrepresented minorities.
